verb.name: accept
verb.desc: Indicates that that the actor has accepted the object. For instance, a person accepting an award, or accepting an assignment.

verb.name: access
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has accessed the object. For instance, a person accessing a room, or accessing a file.

verb.name: acknowledge
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has acknowledged the object. This effectively signals that the actor is aware of the object's existence.

verb.name: add
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has added the object to the target. For instance, adding a photo to an album.

verb.name: agree
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor agrees with the object. For example, a person agreeing with an argument, or expressing agreement with a particular issue.

verb.name: append
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has appended the object to the target. For instance, a person appending a new record to a database.

verb.name: approve
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has approved the object. For instance, a manager might approve a travel request.

verb.name: archive
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has archived the object.

verb.name: assign
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has assigned the object to the target.

verb.name: at
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor is currently located at the object. For instance, a person being at a specific physical location.

verb.name: attach
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has attached the object to the target.For instance, a person attaching a file to a wiki page or an email.

verb.name: attend
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has attended the object. For instance, a person attending a meeting.

verb.name: author
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has authored the object. Note that this is a more specific form of the verb "create".

verb.name: authorize
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has authorized the object. If a target is specified, it means that the authorization is specifically in regards to the target. For instance, a service can authorize a person to access a given application; in which case the actor is the service, the object is the person, and the target is the application. In contrast, a person can authorize a request; in which case the actor is the person and the object is the request and there might be no explicit target.

verb.name: borrow
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has borrowed the object. If a target is specified, it identifies the entity from which the object was borrowed. For instance, if a person borrows a book from a library, the person is the actor, the book is the object and the library is the target.

verb.name: build
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has built the object. For example, if a person builds a model or compiles code.

verb.name: cancel
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has canceled the object. For instance, canceling a calendar event.

verb.name: close
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has closed the object. For instance, the object could represent a ticket being tracked in an issue management system.

verb.name: complete
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has completed the object.

verb.name: confirm
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has confirmed or agrees with the object. For instance, a software developer might confirm an issue reported against a product.

verb.name: consume
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has consumed the object. The specific meaning is dependent largely on the object's type. For instance, an actor may "consume" an audio object, indicating that the actor has listened to it; or an actor may "consume" a book, indicating that the book has been read. As such, the "consume" verb is a more generic form of other more specific verbs such as "read" and "play".

verb.name: checkin
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has checked-in to the object. For instance, a person checking-in to a Place.

verb.name: create
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has created the object.

verb.name: delete
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has deleted the object. This implies, but does not require, the permanent destruction of the object.

verb.name: deliver
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has delivered the object. For example, delivering a package.

verb.name: deny
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has denied the object. For example, a manager may deny a travel request.

verb.name: disagree
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor disagrees with the object.

verb.name: dislike
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor dislikes the object. Note that the "dislike" verb is distinct from the "unlike" verb which assumes that the object had been previously "liked".

verb.name: experience
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has experienced the object in some manner. Note that, depending on the specific object types used for both the actor and object, the meaning of this verb can overlap that of the "consume" and "play" verbs. For instance, a person might "experience" a movie; or "play" the movie; or "consume" the movie. The "experience" verb can be considered a more generic form of other more specific verbs as "consume", "play", "watch", "listen", and "read"

verb.name: favorite
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor marked the object as an item of special interest.

verb.name: find
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has found the object.

verb.name: flag-as-inappropriate
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has flagged the object as being inappropriate for some reason. When using this verb, the context property can be used to provide additional detail about why the object has been flagged.

verb.name: follow
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor began following the activity of the object. In most cases, the objectType will be a "person", but it can potentially be of any type that can sensibly generate activity. Processors MAY ignore (silently drop) successive identical "follow" activities.

verb.name: give
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor is giving an object to the target. Examples include one person giving a badge object to another person. The object identifies the object being given. The target identifies the receiver.

verb.name: host
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor is hosting the object. As in hosting an event, or hosting a service.

verb.name: ignore
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has ignored the object. For instance, this verb may be used when an actor has ignored a friend request, in which case the object may be the request-friend activity.

verb.name: insert
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has inserted the object into the target.

verb.name: install
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has installed the object, as in installing an application.

verb.name: interact
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has interacted with the object. For instance, when one person interacts with another.

verb.name: invite
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has invited the object, typically a person object, to join or participate in the object described by the target. The target could, for instance, be an event, group or a service.

verb.name: join
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has become a member of the object. This specification only defines the meaning of this verb when the object of the Activity has an objectType of group, though implementors need to be prepared to handle other types of objects.

verb.name: leave
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has left the object. For instance, a Person leaving a Group or checking-out of a Place.

verb.name: like
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor marked the object as an item of special interest. The "like" verb is considered to be an alias of "favorite". The two verb are semantically identical.

verb.name: listen
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has listened to the object. This is typically only applicable for objects representing audio content, such as music, an audio-book, or a radio broadcast. The "listen" verb is a more specific form of the "consume", "experience" and "play" verbs.

verb.name: lose
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has lost the object. For instance, if a person loses a game.

verb.name: make-friend
verb.desc: Indicates the creation of a friendship that is reciprocated by the object. Since this verb implies an activity on the part of its object, processors MUST NOT accept activities with this verb unless they are able to verify through some external means that there is in fact a reciprocated connection. For example, a processor may have received a guarantee from a particular publisher that the publisher will only use this Verb in cases where a reciprocal relationship exists.

verb.name: open
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has opened the object. For instance, the object could represent a ticket being tracked in an issue management system.

verb.name: play
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor spent some time enjoying the object. For example, if the object is a video this indicates that the subject watched all or part of the video. The "play" verb is a more specific form of the "consume" verb.

verb.name: present
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has presented the object. For instance, when a person gives a presentation at a conference.

verb.name: purchase
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has purchased the object. If a target is specified, in indicates the entity from which the object was purchased.

verb.name: qualify
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has qualified for the object. If a target is specified, it indicates the context within which the qualification applies.

verb.name: read
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor read the object. This is typically only applicable for objects representing printed or written content, such as a book, a message or a comment. The "read" verb is a more specific form of the "consume", "experience" and "play" verbs.

verb.name: receive
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor is receiving an object. Examples include a person receiving a badge object. The object identifies the object being received.

verb.name: reject
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has rejected the object.

verb.name: remove
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has removed the object from the target.

verb.name: remove-friend
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has removed the object from the collection of friends.

verb.name: replace
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has replaced the target with the object.

verb.name: request
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has requested the object. If a target is specified, it indicates the entity from which the object is being requested.

verb.name: request-friend
verb.desc: Indicates the creation of a friendship that has not yet been reciprocated by the object.

verb.name: resolve
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has resolved the object. For instance, the object could represent a ticket being tracked in an issue management system.

verb.name: return
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has returned the object. If a target is specified, it indicates the entity to which the object was returned.

verb.name: retract
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has retracted the object. For instance, if an actor wishes to retract a previously published activity, the object would be the previously published activity that is being retracted.

verb.name: rsvp-maybe
verb.desc: The "possible RSVP" verb indicates that the actor has made a possible RSVP for the object. This specification only defines the meaning of this verb when its object is an event, though implementors need to be prepared to handle other object types. The use of this verb is only appropriate when the RSVP was created by an explicit action by the actor. It is not appropriate to use this verb when a user has been added as an attendee by an event organiser or administrator.

verb.name: rsvp-no
verb.desc: The "negative RSVP" verb indicates that the actor has made a negative RSVP for the object. This specification only defines the meaning of this verb when its object is an event, though implementors need to be prepared to handle other object types. The use of this verb is only appropriate when the RSVP was created by an explicit action by the actor. It is not appropriate to use this verb when a user has been added as an attendee by an event organiser or administrator.

verb.name: rsvp-yes
verb.desc: The "positive RSVP" verb indicates that the actor has made a positive RSVP for an object. This specification only defines the meaning of this verb when its object is an event, though implementors need to be prepared to handle other object types. The use of this verb is only appropriate when the RSVP was created by an explicit action by the actor. It is not appropriate to use this verb when a user has been added as an attendee by an event organiser or administrator.

verb.name: satisfy
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has satisfied the object. If a target is specified, it indicate the context within which the object was satisfied. For instance, if a person satisfies the requirements for a particular challenge, the person is the actor; the requirement is the object; and the challenge is the target.

verb.name: save
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has called out the object as being of interest primarily to him- or herself. Though this action MAY be shared publicly, the implication is that the object has been saved primarily for the actor's own benefit rather than to show it to others as would be indicated by the "share" verb.

verb.name: schedule
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has scheduled the object. For instance, scheduling a meeting.

verb.name: search
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor is or has searched for the object. If a target is specified, it indicates the context within which the search is or has been conducted.

verb.name: sell
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has sold the object. If a target is specified, it indicates the entity to which the object was sold.

verb.name: send
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has sent the object. If a target is specified, it indicates the entity to which the object was sent.

verb.name: share
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has called out the object to readers. In most cases, the actor did not create the object being shared, but is instead drawing attention to it.

verb.name: sponsor
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has sponsored the object. If a target is specified, it indicates the context within which the sponsorship is offered. For instance, a company can sponsor an event; or an individual can sponsor a project; etc.

verb.name: start
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has started the object. For instance, when a person starts a project.

verb.name: stop-following
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has stopped following the object.

verb.name: submit
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has submitted the object. If a target is specified, it indicates the entity to which the object was submitted.

verb.name: tag
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has associated the object with the target. For example, if the actor specifies that a particular user appears in a photo. the object is the user and the target is the photo.

verb.name: terminate
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has terminated the object.

verb.name: tie
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has neither won or lost the object. This verb is generally only applicable when the object represents some form of competition, such as a game.

verb.name: unfavorite
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has removed the object from the collection of favorited items.

verb.name: unlike
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has removed the object from the collection of liked items.

verb.name: unsatisfy
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has not satisfied the object. If a target is specified, it indicates the context within which the object was not satisfied. For instance, if a person fails to satisfy the requirements of some particular challenge, the person is the actor; the requirement is the object and the challenge is the target.

verb.name: unsave
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has removed the object from the collection of saved items.

verb.name: unshare
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor is no longer sharing the object. If a target is specified, it indicates the entity with whom the object is no longer being shared.

verb.name: update
verb.desc: The "update" verb indicates that the actor has modified the object. Use of the "update" verb is generally reserved to indicate modifications to existing objects or data such as changing an existing user's profile information.

verb.name: use
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has used the object in some manner.

verb.name: watch
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has watched the object. This verb is typically applicable only when the object represents dynamic, visible content such as a movie, a television show or a public performance. This verb is a more specific form of the verbs "experience", "play" and "consume".

verb.name: win
verb.desc: Indicates that the actor has won the object. This verb is typically applicable only when the object represents some form of competition, such as a game.
